entry.title: The Unfinished In-between
entry.content:
My story is paced in a notebook,
filled with unfinished, written, blank pages,
torn at the crease, screaming
to be different.

I try to fit you in between the pages,
as your sharp edge deepens the old wound
and tears my scars anew.
You said sorry, but that didn‚Äôt stop the edge from cutting,
the skin from bleeding,
the heart from hurting.

The word ‚Äòsorry‚Äô coming out of your mouth,
natural as a reflex,
has shielded you from guilt one moment to the next,
now an empty nothing once sweet.

Perhaps it was you who depleted every ounce of its meaning
one too many times.
A hollow shell of broken intentions
fell silently on my page,
putting an end to our undone story.

entry.title: Again
entry.content:
Baby girl, you‚Äôre gonna love again
This time, it will be better than the last
The shattered dreams, the broken pieces from the past
Will be tender, and filled with love again
The unnamed promises, hopeless romance
Will be replaced by the warm presence of the heart
and of the voice that says ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here.‚Äù

My sweet, I once had this fear
Of being an unlovable driftwood
Holding on to any shore,
calling it home,
giving it my heart
Time and time again
Hope fades away,
with rain and tears,
with wind and shivers and hurts
Then comes one day
Autumn breeze tells me
‚ÄúBaby girl, you‚Äôre gonna love again.‚Äù

entry.title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)
entry.content:
I just watched ‚ÄúEternal Sunshine‚Äù for the second time. I feel differently about the movie this time. Surprisingly I like this frame:

Having someone with whom you once felt so happy you could die being erased from your memory seems like a relief at first and unbearable once you realize how many happy memories are actually leaving you. It hurts me to see how Joel hurts Clem; assumptions building up to judgments eventually kill the image of the other person in your mind.

Some of the scenes I like:

  • The scene with two kids: Baby girl in pink cow boy hat held baby Joel‚Äôs hand and walked him out away from the bullying kids. Then they went home, with baby Joel placing a pillow on the baby girl‚Äôs face in front of the house. Baby Joel‚Äôs mom saw them, both of them waved at her: We‚Äôre just playin‚Äô! It‚Äôs such a sweet scene.

  • The scene at the end of the erasing procedure, with the beach house:

What if you‚Äôd stay this time?
Come back and make up a goodbye, at least.
Let‚Äôs pretend we had one.

Let‚Äôs pretend we had one. Shall we? Gosh, how much I cried on this line.

Joel told Clem that he was scared, that‚Äôs why he walked out the door. She didn‚Äôt know he was scared. He thought she knew that about him. It seems to me that this is the first time they were vulnerable with each other, and it happens to be at the end of their story, or at least the end of his memory about her that he wanted to erase. I noticed there is this one scene when Joel admitted to Clem that he was scared, he had a genuine, relieved, beautiful smile:

For a long time, I have had this habit in my head: Memories passing by, as if I‚Äôm on the train and I see them from the window, one after the other, or they‚Äôre on the train, and I‚Äôm at the station watching them go by. Either way, they‚Äôre passing right before my eyes. I see that exact kind of motion in ‚ÄúEternal Sunshine,‚Äù which is interesting to have your imagination actualized.

I realized I resisted the urge to fix these characters; I didn‚Äôt want to change them. They just happened to be that way‚Ä¶

entry.title: Would you lie to me?
entry.content:
Would you lie to me?
Pretending that you care
When I‚Äôm awfully lonely

Would you lie to me?
Pretending that you‚Äôre there
When I‚Äôm facing my worst fear
Of being abandoned, having no one near

Would you lie to me?
Saying you want me close
Even though you don‚Äôt mean it
I just needed
to hear
someone says it.

entry.title: A sense of belonging
entry.content:
The holidays are around the corner‚Ä¶ of course I feel sad. I know that I can video call my family in VN, but I still miss the feeling of having a family by my side, a sense of belonging with my beloved in person, I guess. I thought of going back to ATL, but I don‚Äôt feel very welcomed just thinking about it; I guess I deserve more than that. Having a friend to keep me in check is great, which prevented me from jumping voluntarily into a potential dumpster fire.

A sense of belonging, being understood of where I‚Äôm coming from, where I‚Äôm heading towards and being loved for that. Wouldn‚Äôt that be wonderful? Feels good to be able to put it into words (finally? partially? I don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôm happy with this.)

This will be the first time I spend all Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year by myself. I am pretty sure I do not feel this way when I am in VN around this time of year; probably, the atmosphere and the holiday spirit are differently appreciated here. No more AZ, no more GA. I looked up tickets to Taylor‚Äôs comedy shows, which returned a very pricey journey to NY, which I would not want to go by myself. Travels are off. (Ugh?) But let‚Äôs think about all the money we‚Äôll save and get to spend somewhere else‚Ä¶ Being a broke-ass international phd student in the midst of a pandemic sucks. I‚Äôm not gonna lie. I occasionally take pride in the fact that I made it this far. That journey entails tons of hardship. I can name one of them right now - isolation. The path you take, the choices (mistakes) you make, lead you to whatever hellhole you‚Äôre in now.

In another optimistic news, I‚Äôm just so happy to find out about thriftbooks. I don‚Äôt feel like I have to scroll forever to find a cheap version of a book I wanted to read. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I love the convenience of ebook, with highlighting and looking up terms and whatnot. But the feeling of holding a physical book in your hands, the sound of a highlighter gently moving on the rusty paper, just hit differently.

entry.title: Do I do stuff, even...
entry.content:
Yup. I guess I do.

üé∂

I play the ukulele, baritone ukulele and a little bit guitar, and I like to sing along. I have this little place on soundcloud for all my random moments: https://soundcloud.com/huyendoesstuff/

At first I just put it all there, to save the moments for me. But later, there was this friend of mine who said to me that she actually liked these audios. And listening to them‚Ä¶ means something to her. It warms my heart just thinking about that :)

‚úçüèº

Ah yes, this blog‚Ä¶

No doubts that I like writing ‚Äì The reason for the existence of this very page. Most importantly, how to put one word after one another that closely reflect how I feel ‚Äì That‚Äôs the beauty of the whole thing, learning to express myself, and also learning about myself.

üì∏

Sometimes I take pictures here and there https://www.instagram.com/huyendoesstuff/

‚Ä¶ Onto the professional stuff:

üíª

I am currently a PhD candidate in Computer Science, doing research in Data Visualization. So basically I code and make visualizations that reveal what data is trying to express.

My public code is at github: https://github.com/huyen-nguyen

üìù

Um and I write manucripts - as a big part of research work. But this a is different kind of writing, which involves less spontaneity and more rigorous methodology.

My publication page: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=tsrO-ZgAAAAJ&hl=en

üë©üèª‚Äçüè´

‚Ä¶ and lastly, my very professional site: huyennguyen.com

entry.title: My books
entry.content:
As a very recent reader of books, here is my little collection, in the order that I read:

1. No Hard Feelings: The Secret Power of Embracing Emotions at Work, by Liz Fosslien, Mollie West Duffy

Keywords: Quotes and stories.
3/10
2. The Four Agreements: A Practical Guide to Personal Freedom (A Toltec Wisdom Book), by don Miguel Ruiz

Keywords: Spirituality, extreme opinions, self awareness, love.
8/10
3. The Missing Piece Meets The BIG O, by Shel Silverstein

Keywords: Proactive self improvement, self acceptance.
9/10

entry.title: It's been a while
entry.content:
Oh, hello, you!

It‚Äôs been a while since the last time I was here. Oh, it‚Äôs exactly 9 months: January 12 and October 12. Interesting.

One new thing I learn since the last time I was here is that I need to build the site with jekyll build, then take only whatever within the _site folder and put them in the branch for deploying. I was doing it all wrong‚Äîno wonder why it didn‚Äôt work as I expected.

I moved back to the US. Things have been crazy in the last four months. So many things happened.

I teach now, so I guess I‚Äôm a teacher?! Still feel very fresh in the role. I‚Äôm truly happy I got to do what I love, and I love what I do.

One thing I know now is that we learn better by example. If you never witness a woman lifts a 200-pound weight, you may not even believe these kinds of thing happen. But it is true. You witness it, and you believe that a human being can do it, and then you believe you can do it.

I recently got hooked with reddit. I feel like I can be mindful and intentional about the topics that I want to see, instead of feeds with overflowing recommended contents or updates of someone whose life may not be of my interest.

entry.title: The narrative on moving through life
entry.content:
It‚Äôs been uneasy for me to write this down, but because of the amount of gratitude I held dearly in my heart for the support I got from these sensational words, I decided to start this one.

Here‚Äôs the tweet that has changed the game for me:

here‚Äôs to the people who‚Äôs trauma did not give them thick skin. the ones who became more sensitive and insecure, who cry more easily, who get overwhelmed at small things. i‚Äôm so tired of the narrative that trauma makes you tough and untouchable. we‚Äôre survivors, not superheroes.

‚Äî‚Äì jules rylan ‚ú°Ô∏é @radiantbutch ¬∑ Jan 4, 2021

I was speechless and emotional after reading the statement. I have always been an emotional person. But this hit hard, and different. For the first time I feel like I‚Äôm free from the expectation where I should be ok by now, now that I understand I don‚Äôt necessarily have to end my story with a forced positive note.
